newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP sees 1997 sales growth under 30 pct.
newsitem.headline: SAP sees 1997 sales growth under 30 pct.

text.p: SAP AG, the German business software group, said late on Wednesday that it did not expect sales growth next year to exceed 30 percent.
SAP board member Henning Kagermann told German television that the company must get used to lower growth rates in the future.
"For 1997 that means that sales growth will probably be under 30 percent," he told N-TV television.

SAP, the world's leading manufacturer of client-server business application software, stunned markets this week when it reported that sales and pre-tax profit in the first nine months of the year grew considerably slower than expected.
The company was forced to abandon earlier forecasts of achieving sales and profit growth of around 40 percent this year, cutting the outlook to just over 30 percent.

SAP shares were pounded on Wednesday, falling as much as 26 percent and dragging down the DAX index of 30 blue-chips. The company's preferred stock, which is listed in the DAX index, plunged 24 percent on the day to close at 212 marks.
